reviewText: For all the people that do not recommend this game: you should probably stop buying games that are older than you :)\nNow about the game: It was and still is a great RTS and keep in mind this came out in 2001. It brings back so many good memories and bad (when my WWIII:BG CD got scratched and couldn't play the game anymore). I recommend this game to people that started gaming with 8-bit graphics games, not with COD and CS :)
voteText: 153 of 180 people (85%) found this review helpful 28 people found this review funny

reviewText: Boy was I excited when I saw this title on Steam. WWIII:BG is the first real video game I've ever layed and I absolutely loved it. While the gameplay itself may not be up to 2013 RTS standards, the music, ambience, mission creativity, mechanics, and immersion are top notch for its time. Sure there are annoying pathing bugs and stupid AI, but it's definitely not gamebreaking. A nostalgic 10/10.

reviewText: Why all the hate? Do not buy this game now if you don't collect games or if you haven't played the game before. I got WWIII:BG the date it appeared on steam out of nostalgia; I used to play it years ago.\n\nIf you're actually looking for a good new flashy RTS game look elsewhere (hell, even World in Conflict), don't hate on this game just because it's old. (that being said the map engine was awesome at the time. heavily changing terrain during gameplay, building structures, hidden units, etc.)

reviewText: A fun albeit, dated, rts that gives you the most enjoyment from the skirmishes. reviewText:
First let me sy that I got this for a steal on sale, so can't complain too much, but

Graphics are ok (cir 2005 style), blocky 3D but effective enough
Typical RTS Gameplay, not much reasource management, just drill for Oil -> Money, focus on combat and base bulding

However, overall, this is a pretty flawed game, based on what I played at least (US campaign, then got bored).

Its tough even on normal difficulty, odds are often stacked against you, and silly restrictions (in single player campaign) such as this 1 unit must survive, and no repair capability offered, even between levels!!!?

Enemy AI is pretty simple, but effective enough... units will stay where they are, didn't see a lit of patrolling, and then they swarm as soon as you attack. Own team AI is where most of the problems are... can only set 3 basic tactics per unit/group... chase 'em, stand still, or stay within area. Even on stay within, you units often roam into areas they shouldn't and get picked off easy. Wost part is the route finding... the game relies on building many units and swarming when you outnumber the enemy... often groups of 15-20 units per group. But the pathfinding is bad. often the first 3 or 4 units head in the right direction, and the ones behind bump intoi them and then head off in another direction for an alternate, often with disasterous effects.

Base building is pretty noddy too. no sign of upgrades for most buildings, just build one to access a certain list of units and then forget it. Having to manage power was a nice touch (each gen can power two nearby buildings) which gives some tactical options of blacking-out your enemy buildings... but most of the time you'll get mashed before you get near ur enemies gens.

All in all this seems a dissapointing basic RTS cir 2000... if you want a very cheap nostagic RTS shot then grab it on sale, if not avoid, there are much better ones out there.

reviewText: Had this game when I was much younger, absolutely loved this game and any other RTS game. Most people probably wont know this game but Dogs of War : Battle on Primus IV (came out in 2000) was my favourite RTS game back then. You could either control vehicles from an eagles eye view or directly control a vehicle in 3rd person, which was my favorite feature of the game. The game doesn't have that feature however, I still loved playing it. The game is pretty difficult but that's what makes it fun for me. Sometimes the AI is really frustrating but that does not bother me too much. Graphics are of course dated. Overall, loved the game and still do 8/10.

reviewText: Be very careful and look at the date of release before you think of buying this. It's 13 YEARS OLD!! The release date of 2001 is in very small print.\nThe videos above make it look like a modern game. However, these aren't in game graphics, just footage from cut scenes. When I bought this game, it was being advertised on the main Store screen as being new!" However that is deliberately misleading and this has now become a very vocal and major issue of the way Steam is deliberately misleading it's customers (some are saying "downright rip off" on many gaming sites and gaming focused YouTube channels).\nI find this very sad as Steam used to be held in high regard by myself and many
date: many others for it's integrity and honesty to it's customers.\nAs for the gameplay of WW3: Black Gold
recommended: it looks very dated now and has been left way behind by so many more modern games in the RTS genre. It just can't be compared to more modern RTS games in ANY possible way.\nI bought this game and before playing it
hoursPlayed: went to visit my big time PC gaming neighbour. By coincidence
voteText: he was playing the game and was ranting how he had been "conned" by Steam and cursing the game and it's gameplay. So I sat watching him playing it for a few hours
helpfulPercent: hoping it would get better the further he got into the game. It didn't.\nSo when I got back home
votesHelpful: I uninstalled it and never bothered with it again. So I haven't logged even a minute of gameplay on it on my own computer. What I saw at my friend's was enough for me.\nSo when I want an RTS fix
votesTotal: I go for Company of Heroes 1 and 2
votesFunny: Starcraft 2 (both of the already finished games of the intended trilogy)
commentsCount: the Warhammer RTS games and the Paradox Grand Strategy games such as Hearts of Iron 3 TFH
column17: etc.\nSo the lesson to be learned here is that Steam is quickly losing it's integrity and high regard in the gaming industry and so be careful to look at all the small print in the advertising for EVERY game it sells. Plus
column18: assume "new" means the game is new to being available on Steam and not necessarily new as in made in 2014.\nI really hope this isn't a downhill spiral and that Steam gets back to how it used to be which made it essential to all PC gamers."
